Award.AwardTitle: RCN-UBE Incubator: Consortium for the Integration of Ethical Research Practices into Course-based Undergraduate Research Experiences in the Biological Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
Course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) have emerged as a viable mechanism to increase student access to authentic scientific opportunities. Current evidence in the bioeducation literature indicates that student engagement in CUREs results in significant gains in their development of scientific reasoning skills, attitudes, and persistence in the domain. Authentic research experiences have likewise been shown to positively influence students' interest in scientific inquiry and their ability to "think like a scientist." While the above corpus of research has focused extensively on student outcomes within CUREs, more recent efforts have articulated the need to examine the extent to which contextual features and affordances within such learning environments mediate students' academic and professional development. Among these factors, the ability to conduct research in an ethical and responsible manner is argued to be of critical value, as it is one of the hallmarks of rigorous scientific investigation. Although the need to engender ethical and responsible research practices in students is therefore apparent, to the best of our knowledge, no studies have examined the integration of ethics/RCR education within CURE contexts, despite its broader importance to professionalism within the scientific community. Furthermore, it is unclear to what extent existent ethics/RCR frameworks are amenable to CURE instruction.

The proposed initiative seeks to address these concerns through the formation of a consortium and structured activities that will foster sustainable relationships between individuals from diverse organizations, including minority-serving institutions, two-year colleges, research universities, and professional societies, who will be tasked with the exploration of ethics and responsible conduct of research within CUREs in the biological sciences. Specifically, network activities and products will: a) define and describe the current state of ethics/RCR education within bioscience CUREs; b) detail the perceptions of postdoctoral fellows, faculty, and administrators responsible for teaching and scholarship in the areas of CURE implementation and bioethics in regard to the long-term role of ethics/RCR in research-driven courses; and c) enhance both participants' and the publics' knowledge of ethics education in the context of authentic, research-based coursework through the dissemination of a public consortium website, presentations, and publications.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (BIO), Division of Biological Infrastructure, and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources (EHR), Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) serve as an effective model for maximizing student engagement in the authentic process of scientific discovery. Notably, current evidence in the literature indicates that participation in CUREs enhances students' science identity development, acquisition of scientific process skills, and ability to "think like a scientist." Collectively, these outcomes are found to mediate students' interest in pursuing future research-related opportunities in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.

 

Despite the salient importance of these findings, however, little emphasis has been placed on the contextual features of CUREs that impact cognitive and non-cognitive student outcomes, including the formation of a culture of research within such learning environments. Central to that discussion is ethics and responsible conduct of research (E/RCR) education, which informs not only the rigor of scientific investigations, but also the broader public's trust in science. Because CUREs often enroll students from a diversity of academic majors (both STEM and non-STEM), incorporation of E/RCR instruction into CUREs can ostensibly have a direct impact on the formation of an ethically-responsible citizenry and workforce. We contend, therefore, that examination of E/RCR within CUREs is a necessary area for future scholarship.

 

With generous support from the NSF RCN-UBE Incubator initiative, the Ethics Network for Course-based Opportunities in Undergraduate Research (ENCOUR) was created in 2018 as a platform for addressing the aforementioned need. Specifically, ENCOUR sought to promote the formation of a community of educators, researchers, and administrators from a diversity of institutions and with diverse educational backgrounds who possessed a commitment to effective integration of E/RCR education into CUREs in the biological sciences. Furthermore, the goals of ENCOUR included: (a) formulation of student learning objectives (SLOs) associated with E/RCR core tenets described in the literature; (b) identification and collation of existent E/RCR curricular and assessment tools, which could be adapted for use in CUREs; and (c) evaluation of current E/RCR practices employed by CURE facilitators nationwide.

 

In order to actualize the above goals, a group of 18 leaders in CURE development, implementation, and evaluation as well as bioethics convened at The University of Texas at El Paso in January 2018 for the inaugural ENCOUR meeting. During this meeting, ENCOUR members developed recommendations for advancing E/RCR education efforts within CUREs, including the genesis of six SLOs centered around CURE students' E/RCR knowledge and attitudes in the discipline as well as the formation of a database of E/RCR resources, which can be found on the ENCOUR website (https://encour.utep.edu). Attendees also began the process of drafting a national survey designed to generate a representative account of E/RCR educational methods adopted by CURE practitioners, which was later distributed through science education listservs in late spring.

 

Outcomes of the inaugural meeting were synthesized into a meeting report, published in CBE-Life Sciences Education, and were likewise presented at several conferences with the intent of recruiting new ENCOUR members and increasing the science and science education community's awareness of the importance of E/RCR education in CUREs. Results of the national survey, which garnered more than 60 responses, are currently being prepared for publication (anticipated January 2020 submission). We feel fortunate that ENCOUR continues to receive financial support through the NSF RCN-UBE mechanism and are committed to the continued growth of ENCOUR as a community dedicated to the advancement of E/RCR education in the biological sciences and beyond.
